title: O'Rourke: Religious institutions should lose tax-exempt status if they oppose same-sex marriage
text:
Democratic presidential hopeful Beto O'Rourke Beto O'RourkeO'Rourke eyes workplace protections for women, parents Krystal Ball: Yang campaign a 'triumph of substance over the theatre' Delaney: I wouldn't allow VP's family members to sit on foreign boards MORE said Thursday that religious institutions should lose their tax-exempt status if they oppose same-sex marriage.

"Do you think religious institutions like colleges, churches, charities, should they lose their tax-exempt status if they oppose same sex marriage?" CNN anchor Don Lemon Don Carlton LemonFox rejects Biden request to not run Trump campaign ad CNN refuses to run Biden-Ukraine ad by Trump campaign Egos! Ratings! Marketing! Oh my — the real clash in every debate MORE asked O'Rourke at the network's Equality Townhall.

ADVERTISEMENT

"Yes," the former Texas congressman responded. "There can be no reward, no benefit, no tax break, for anyone, or any institution, any organization in America that denies the full human rights and the full civil rights of every single one of us."

"As president, we're going to make that a priority and we are going to stop those who are infringing upon the human rights of our fellow Americans," he said.

The response is likely to receive pushback from certain religious groups, which have long opposed efforts to remove their tax-exempt status. Critics have said they oppose same-sex marriage due to their religious beliefs.

Sen. Cory Booker Cory Anthony BookerThe Hill's Morning Report - White House escalates impeachment battle royal Fifth DNC debate to be held Nov. 20 in Georgia Yang becomes eighth Democrat to qualify for November presidential debate MORE (D-N.J.) was asked the same question earlier at the town hall Thursday night, but declined to give a yes or no answer.

“I’m not saying, because I know this is a long legal battle. I’m not dodging your question. I’m saying I believe fundamentally that discrimination is discrimination,” Booker said.

“And if you are using your position to try to discriminate others, there must be consequences to that. And I will make sure to hold them accountable using the DOJ or whatever investigatory. You cannot discriminate," he added.
description: Democratic presidential hopeful Beto O'Rourke said Thursday that religious institutions should lose their tax-exempt status if they oppose same-sex marriage.
